slidelink.displaytext: Smart Home, Home Automation & Intelligent Building Concepts
Smart Home, Home Automation & Intelligent Building Concepts
Cyber Physical Systems (CPS), IoT, and IIoT - 1
Cyber Physical Systems (CPS), IOT, and IIOT - 2

search.slidetext: help to complete this lesson: review the lesson content complete the tutorial tasks attend the live chat post in the discussion forum contact your module leader is chitra balakrishna: chitra.balakrishna@nccedu.com additional resources see business computing and information systems main page see business computing and information systems main page see business computing and information systems main page see business computing and information systems main page corporate communication systems management topic 12 completion 0% 25% 50% 75% 100% 0% lesson: uclan@nccedu.com contact on completion of this topic you should be able to : describe a set of real-world wsn implementations document the commercial suppliers of wsn infrastructure give an overview of the software used in wsn implementations explain how the epc and iot concepts inter-relate document the commercial suppliers of rfid infrastructure (and costs) additional resources these are additional resources to help you out. begin begin begin begin begin begin wireless sensor networks
topic 12 wireless sensor networks corporate communication systems management

what will you learn? wireless sensor networks the defining characteristics of a wsn the defining characteristics of a wsn the typical applications of a wsn the typical applications of a wsn the role of rfid as a pre-cursor to wsn the role of rfid as a pre-cursor to wsn wsn standards and protocols wsn standards and protocols wsn-related technologies and concepts wsn-related technologies and concepts strengths & weaknesses of a wsn strengths & weaknesses of a wsn the architecture of a wsn and its components the architecture of a wsn and its components

learning outcomes describe a set of real-world wsn implementations describe a set of real-world wsn implementations 1 1 document the commercial suppliers of wsn infrastructure document the commercial suppliers of wsn infrastructure 2 2 give an overview of the software used in wsn implementations give an overview of the software used in wsn implementations 3 3 document the commercial suppliers of rfid infrastructure (and costs) document the commercial suppliers of rfid infrastructure (and costs) 5 5 explain how the epc and iot concepts inter-relate explain how the epc and iot concepts inter-relate 4 4

cloud fundamental cloud themes virtualisation uses virtualisation (physical => logical mapping) remoteness remoteness and complexity hidden from users resources shared resources are utilised to maximum degree hardware highly scalable, using cheap commodity hardware access real-time access via high bandwidth connections model large-scale, distributed & remote resources what is a wsn? power, range, frequency, protocols & standards wireless issues size, cost, construction, lifespan, behaviour type sensor issues topology, scale/size, location, application/function network issues wireless sensor network network of sensors communicating wirelessly!

wireless sensor network sensors - 1 definition of a sensor smart sensors a device which detects or measures a physical property and records, indicates, or otherwise responds to it. are built as iot components that convert the real-world variable that theyre measuring into a digital data stream for transmission to a gateway.
transduction (measurement) computation communication control sensors wireless sensor network sensors - 2 move intelligence closer to point of measurement integrate into a distributed sensor network

micro electro-mechanical systems piezo-resistive effect (strain => electrical resistance) piezo-electric effect (force/stress => voltage change) capacitive sensors (force/stress => capacity change) magnetic & electro-magnetic sensors (no contact) transducers convert energy from one domain to another physical property => electrical signal (volt/current) transducers transducers transducers mems mems mems sensors transducers and mems

motes a tiny speck the size of a dust particle the smallest granule of sensor size others thermal sensors (heat => electric signal) optical sensors (light => electric signal) acoustic sensors (sound => electric signal) chemical sensors (reactions => electric signal) others others others motes motes motes sensors others

shipping containers and pallets passports, contactless card payments animal and pet tracking uhf hf lf rfid frequencies wireless sensor networks life before wsn pure identification chips* to replace barcodes with an epc more computation & on-chip memory wsn wireless sensor networks life before wsn an rfid chip allows (contactless) tracking of that object tag = microchip (with unique id) + antenna fixed/hand-held scanner/reader interrogates tag passive rfid no on-chip power supply active rfid on-chip power supply reader/scanner supplies energy via em waves wireless sensor networks life before wsn radio frequency (wireless) identification (recording/transmitting) wireless sensor networks life before wsn and in the beginning, there was rfid

microchip & memory transceiver /antenna wireless sensor networks sensors as nodes small, autonomous, low-power, wireless devices (as in network node) one or more sensors (one per physical property) a low-power source (battery/solar-power cell) a mini, self-contained computer out on its own

wireless sensor networks variable (mote = smallest) *less important for rfid (no sticking/embedding) variable (see tutorial) depends on application/size of network/lifespan size cost independent units but cooperate with other nodes both impact technical parameters of node relay sensor data out of network to collection point often use multi-hop model via routing or flooding sensors as nodes - 2
wsn topology wireless sensor networks

communications wake up, detect other sensors and communicate based on mobile phone industry cells/base stations self-organisation & location wireless sensor networks positioning positioning relative to neighbouring sensors (network localisation) absolute to physical target (environmental fixing) self-organisation & location wireless sensor networks communications positioning communications self-organisation & location wireless sensor networks n x smart sensors = wsn wsn = ad-hoc, multi-hop, mesh topology

handling outputs wireless sensor networks signal processing sensor fusion => kalman filter => dsp merging of n different sensor outputs logic & decision-making => intelligence signal conditioning primary versus secondary properties remove noise, distortion => snr produce clean electrical signal. signal capturing a sensor captured a temperature and converted it into electrical impulse/ signal

wireless sensor networks applications: telemetry - 1 traffic flows, vehicle densities & road usage animal migration & population densities battlefield surveillance & perimeter monitoring industrial, scientific & security data: sensors often capture environmental data: temperature, humidity & air quality air pressure, wind speeds, water purity vibration, volcanic & seismic activity

applications: telemetry - 2 wireless sensor networks to harvest ambient data from the environment shipped back and turned into information to monitor and control the environment provides inputs to smart environments volcanoes, deserts, glaciers, jungles etc. industrial extremes, battlefield/conflict zones wsn best for hostile & remote environments wsn can be used in two ways:

desirable features wireless sensor networks ease/speed of installation reliable & robust cheap & power efficient dont hang around in hostile environments! remote & hostile settings => little human contact self identification & self organising talk to other sensors, pass data along large in number, small in size => money & energy!

ieee 1451 ieee/nist standard for smart sensor networks transducer /network interface standard https://www.nist.gov/el/intelligent-systems-division-73500/ieee-1451 https://www.nist.gov/el/intelligent-systems-division-73500/ieee-1451 https://www.nist.gov/el/intelligent-systems-division-73500/ieee-1451 https://www.nist.gov/el/intelligent-systems-division-73500/ieee-1451 zigbee low-power, wireless sensor & control networks builds m2m wsn and iot infrastructures/products https://zigbeealliance.org/ https://zigbeealliance.org/ https://zigbeealliance.org/ https://zigbeealliance.org/ wireless hart protocol hart = highway addressable remote transducer smart device/field instrument control protocol https://fieldcommgroup.org/technologies/hart https://fieldcommgroup.org/technologies/hart https://fieldcommgroup.org/technologies/hart https://fieldcommgroup.org/technologies/hart hart hart hart zigbee zigbee zigbee ieee 1451 ieee 1451 ieee 1451 wsn standards & protocols

modest number of (higher power) expensive hosts require more maintenance & human interaction transmit lots of data, have much higher data rates wlan = ieee 802.11 = wi-fi wsn vs. wlan wireless sensor networks wsn large number of (low power) cheap nodes nodes = low maintenance, little human contact nodes send small amounts of data, low data rates wsn wsn vs. wlan wireless sensor networks wlan wsn wlan wsn vs. wlan wireless sensor networks

wireless sensor networks check out each subtopic: m2m technologies m2m technologies m2m technologies the internet of things concept the internet of things concept the internet of things concept smart dust & sensor webs projects smart dust & sensor webs projects smart dust & sensor webs projects smart metering & smart grid concepts smart metering & smart grid concepts smart metering & smart grid concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) click next > or on a subtopic to begin

remote device sensor, meter or appliance m2m m2m wireless sensor networks captures a reading/measurement/event transmitted through network (wired or wireless) to another computer running an application can send control data back to remote device remote control of appliances = home automation

iot wireless sensor networks physical objects (and humans?) = things compare to non-physical data/information make things uniquely identifiable on internet relies on rfid to capture data about things internet of things need huge address space => ipv6 see auto-id labs & electronic product code

wireless sensor networks smart dust project smart dust project an attempt to fabricate mm3 mote sensor nasa sensor webs project a global surveillance network

smart metering wireless sensor networks see the smart energy & open smart grid protocol intelligent sensing/monitoring/control of utilities also called smart grids uses an ami (advanced metering infrastructure) links smart utility reader => remote control centre site-specific, time-specific, real-time data streams

topic 12 you are now at click next > or on a subtopic to begin m2m technologies m2m technologies the internet of things concept the internet of things concept smart dust & sensor webs projects smart dust & sensor webs projects smart metering & smart grid concepts smart metering & smart grid concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) mobile ad-hoc networks (manet)

smart home & home automation wireless sensor networks intelligent building concept the centralised and/or remote sensing/control of: entertainment systems heating, lighting, ventilation and ac systems security & health monitoring systems put your fridge on the web! z-wave zigbee

topic 12 you are now at click next > or on a subtopic to begin m2m technologies m2m technologies the internet of things concept the internet of things concept smart dust & sensor webs projects smart dust & sensor webs projects smart metering & smart grid concepts smart metering & smart grid concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts smart home, home automation & intelligent building concepts ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) mobile ad-hoc networks (manet)

ubiquitous, pervasive & ambient computing wireless sensor networks distributed & integrated information processing push intelligence out/down to everyday devices ambient intelligence, ubicomp or everyware pushes computing power into things (iot) different scales: motes/mems (smart dust) => macro-sized items different interfaces: non-traditional => tactile, voice, motion etc

industrial iot use of iot in industrial sectors and applications examples enables higher efficiency and reliability in operations robotics, medical devices, software-defined production processes cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot wireless sensor networks iiot internet of things the ability of everyday objects (rather than computers and smartphones) to connect to the internet. kettles, fridges and televisions examples (ncsc, uk) iot cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot wireless sensor networks connect, compute, communicate iot cps vs. iot? cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot wireless sensor networks compute, communicate, control cps cyber-physical systems computation, communication and control components tightly combined with physical processes of industry domains (mechanical, electrical, and chemical) cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot wireless sensor networks cps cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot - 1 wireless sensor networks cps iot iiot

ot vs. it wireless sensor networks ot devices control the physical world ot it systems manage data it ot vs. it? safety-critical system systems whose failure could result in loss of life, significant property damage, or damage to the environment human safety is dependent upon the correct operation of system designed with the intent of curbing the effects of an accident from a hazardous event safetycritical system wireless sensor networks operational technology computing and communication systems to manage, monitor and control industrial operations focusing on the physical devices and processes they use ot ics dcs scada operational technology wireless sensor networks ot ot ot ot vs. it ot vs. it ot vs. it scs scs scs cyber physical systems (cps), iot, and iiot - 2 wireless sensor networks scada ics ot dcs

example military, emergency services, disaster relief no centralised/organised connectivity distributed intelligence across all nodes each node discovers neighbours/topology each node incorporates (dynamic) routing no fixed infrastructure or defined topology set of mobile, independent users (nodes) self-configuring, communicate wirelessly mobile ad-hoc networks (manet) wireless sensor networks no fixed infrastructure or defined topology no centralised/organised connectivity example
